postcontent: This pistol is a rare example of a Walther factory capture. On April 3rd 1945 elements of the 90th US Army Infantry and 11th Armored divisions, captured the Walther factory at Zella-Mehlis, Germany. This was one of the last Walthers assembled by factory workers and was awaiting it's final acceptance before the Walther inspectors feld ahead of the allied advance. A lucky G.I. was able to capture this completed pistol with it's original issue "AKAH" holster and bring it home. Most late war AC marked PPs have mismatching numbers because they were assembled using spare parts from the factory after Germanys surrender, but this example was actually completely finnished by the last Walther employees, making it one of the last ever made by Walther for Nazi Germany. Correct late war "W" stamped phosphate magazine, no import marks, no factory engraved banner, no acceptance stamps, only Eagle/N nitro proofs and matching serial.
